description.p: After you register Alpha Anywhere, you are shown the *[ui:Select Workspace]* dialog. *[ui:Select Workspace]* has two tabs: *[ui:Workspace & Tasks]* and *[ui:News & Updates]*. *[ui:News & Updates]* is where you will find details about new releases for Alpha Anywhere, upcoming webinars and events, and links to informative articles.

*[ui:Workspace & Tasks]* is where you create a new or open an existing workspace. A workspace contains all the files your application needs, including components, JavaScript libraries, images, HTML pages, web pages, and style sheets.

Since this is your first time launching Alpha Anywhere, you will need to create a new workspace before you can start building an application. New workspaces are created using the *[ui:Create a new, empty Workspace]* option:
Select *[ui:Create a new, empty Workspace]* and click OK.
Enter a *[ui:Workspace name]*. In this introductory tutorial, we will name the workspace "HelloWorld".

note.p: Workspaces by default are saved in the "AlphaAnywhere" directory in the User Documents folder. You can change this location if desired using the *[ui:Browse...]* button.

description.p: Click *[ui:OK]* to create the workspace.
The *[ui:Web Projects Control Panel]* is where you manage your web and mobile applications. Here, you can add files, manage security, and deploy.

Let's get familiar with how applications are built and create a simple application with a button that displays a message. To begin, we will need to create a new component. Components are the building blocks of Alpha Anywhere web and mobile applications. There are several different types of components. We'll focus on the UX component in this tutorial.
Select *[ui:All Files]* on the *[ui:Web Projects Control Panel]* to show all files in your project. Right now this will be blank because you have not added any files yet.

tip.p: The type of files you can create with the *[ui:New]* button can be filtered. For example, if *[ui:Javascript Files]* is selected, the *[ui:New]* button creates a new JavaScript file. Selecting *[ui:All Files]* lets you create any type of file.

description.p: Click the *[ui:New]* button.
Select *[ui:Web Component]* and click *[ui:Next]*.
Select *[ui:UX]* and click *[ui:Next]*.
Make sure *[ui:Start with a blank UX Component]* is selected and click *[ui:OK]*.

The UX Builder is where you will do most of your development work. Here you add buttons, fields, and other controls and define how they will operate. The interface is divided into two sections. On the left is where you add controls. On the right is a tree representation of your application. This is currently blank because no controls have been added yet.
Open the *[ui:Controls]* pane.
Click *[ui:Add Control]*.
Select *[ui:[Button]]* from the list to add a button. You can type "button" in the *[ui:Filter]* box to filter the control list.
Enter "Hello" for the text for the button and click *[ui:OK]*.
Now that we've added a control, let's save our work.
Click the *[ui:Save]* button in the toolbar or select *[ui:Save]* under the *[ui:File]* menu.
Enter "helloWorld" in the *[ui:File name]* box and click *[ui:Save]*.

section.title: Add an Action to the Button to Display a Message

description.p: Locate the button's *[ui:click]* event (found in the *[ui:Javascript - (Touch, Mouse, Pointer Events)]* section) and click the [...] smart field button to open the event editor.
With *[ui:Action Javascript]* selected, click *[ui:Add New Action]* to open the Action Javascript picker.
Select *[ui:Message box - Transient]* in the Actions list and click *[ui:OK]*. You can use *[ui:Filter list]* to filter the actions.
Enter "Hello, world!" in the *[ui:Message text]* property.
Change the *[ui:Position]* to "center". This will display the message in the center of the screen.
Click *[ui:OK]* to save the action.
Enter an optional description of the action, i.e. "Display "Hello, world!" message".
Click *[ui:Save]* to save your changes to the event.
Save your work.
Now that the application is built, let's test it out.
